Says Collin to Phoebe, while making of hay,</br>Sweet Phoebe resolve me, and do no say nay?</br>Sin I'se rise with the lark, and I'se roost with the crow,</br>And court yow the day long, why wun yow say no?

PHOEBE.</br>Yow teaze me, and plague me, quite out o' my life,</br>Mun I se, tho'f I like yow not, make yow a wife:</br>Young Roger (when milked) will bring hoame my peayle,</br>On Sunday too treats me with cheesecakes and eale.

COLLIN.</br>When churning the butter or pressing the cheese,</br>When washing your dishes, or shelling of peas,</br>I'se oft steal from my flock, in oth' window I peep</br>And for theanking of yow, love, I'se neaver can sleep.

PHOEBE.</br>In yon cottage so neat, with the trees full of bloom,</br>Pears, apples, and plumbs, and a delicate room,</br>Roger kiss'd me, and hugg'd me, and swore it should be,</br>A lodging for no other female but me.</br>He kisses so sweetly I'se cannot denoy,</br>Shou'd he eask for a thousand, noa, truely, not I;</br>Then teaze me no more, for we ne'er shall agree,</br>Seek another may please yow — yow shanno ha' me.

COLLIN.</br>Con Roger attend on heas stock wet or droye,</br>Con he wash, can he shear, can he cure from the stoye,</br>Con he reap, con he mow, con he pitch, con he stack,</br>In nothing can Roger need I'se turn my back.</br>Tho'se he han a cottage, yet I'se better able,</br>In knowledge and labour to furnish your table,</br>With the sweat o' my browe, I'se resolved to troye,</br>And purchase a cottage for Phoebe and I.</br>
